BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 22, 1916.

THE McCOY HALL CONCERT

The fortieth anniversary of the
founding of Johns Hopkins University is being celebrated today—
Tuesday, February 22.
The address of the day is to be
delivered by his Excellency, Dr.
V. K. Wellington Koo, the Chinese
Minister at Washington. The opening prayer will be given by Rev.
John McDowell, of Brown Memorial Church. During the course of
the exercises, President Goodnow
will make some announcements in
• regards to plans for the University
for the coming year.
The exercises are to begin
promptly at i i o'clock. The faculty
and students will march into the assembly room • of McCoy Hall at
10.4.5. The trustees, the faculty.
the Alumni Council and the official
guests will assemble in Levering
Hall at io.30; at 10.20 the graduate students will assemble in Room
io of McCoy Hall, the medical students in Room 12 and the undergraduates in Room ii. The families of the trustees and faculty will
have seats reserved, for them until
10.45. After the procession has
entered the assembly hall, the remaining seats will be thrown open
tr' the public.
Immediately after the exercises
in McCoy Hall, the Hopkins Club
will hold an informal luncheon for
its members. The holding of such
a luncheon (11 Commemoration Day
has become a tradition with the
club, and always arouses great interest. The House Committee has
sent out invitations to every man
enrolled upon the books, and the
number of acceptants is expected to
be even larger than usual.
This evening, the alumni will hold
their annual meeting and banquet.
The meeting will be held at the
Emerson Hotel at 7 P. M., followed
immediately by the banquet. The
committee in charge of the latter
function consists of J. Perhbroke
Thorn (chairman), Eveleth W.
Bridgman, Robertson Griswold and
Guy T. 0. Hollyday. •
Club to Give Luncheon.

The Johns Hopkins Club will
hold a luncheon today. for all its
members. The House Committee
has sent out invitations to every
man enrolled, and a large crowd
is expected to be present.
- For several years it has been the
custom of the club to give such a
luncheon at the close of the exercises on Commemoration Day.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 22, 1916.

JOHNS HOPKINS MOVES TO HOMEWOOD THIS FALL
TO BE AT HOMEWOOD NEXT FALL
Entire University to Be Moved by Next
Scholastic Year --Various Departments to Be Lodged in Structures Now Completed.

Plans for the change of site of
Johns Hopkins University have
been completed. The University
will begin its next scholastic year
tt Homewood.
The announcement of the decision
of the Board of Trustees to move
this coming fall was made by President Goodnow at the beginning of
the year. It is only lately, however,
that the final details of the plans for
removal have been completed, .and
that a definite idea of the conditions under which the new era at
Homewood will begin has shaped
itself.
Contrary to the opinion at first
prevalent after President Goodflow's announcement, the removal
will not be only partial, but will
include practically every department
of the University. The final arrangements for the housing of each
department are now being formulated, and, while these arrangements arranged that is is confidently excannot be announced as abso:utely pected that these provisions will be

The Physics department will be
lodged in the Engineering Building, although what part of that
structure it will occupy has not as
yet been decided.
It is only the location of the
Chemistry department for next
year which is still doubtful. It is
possible that it will also be placed
in one of the Engineering Buildings, but it is far more probable
that either a temporary building
will be erected for it, or that, for
the time being, it will remain at its
present location. The construction
of a temporary building would entail the expenditure of several thousand dollars, and only a strong feeling on the part of the Trustees and
Faculty that it is advisable for the
entire University to be located at
one spot, and for no single department to remain at the present
Monument street location, will make
the erection of such a building at
all likely.
With the possible exception of
this one department, the entire University will open the next scholastic
year at its new site. Preparations
for the removal are already under
way; each department has been at
work for at least a year upon the
details of its removal.
The plans for the removal of the
library, which presented the most
intricate problem of all, have been
definitely completed. Dr. Raney
has been authorized to proceed with
the actual moving of the books
whenever he sees fit, and, by summer, it is expected that the greater
part of the library will be installed
in its place in the Academic Building.

Although definite plans have not
yet been formulated for the dormitory system at Homewood, the following is the general plan: It is
proposed to build a dormitory with
accommodations for one hundred
men on the Charles street front, immediately back Of the old Carroll
Mansion. The dormitory itself
consist of a main building with two
wings running back, leaving an
open court between them. It will
be fireproof throughout and will be
heated and lighted by the present
power-house. There will be no private baths in the dormitory, but
there will be a shower for every
eight or ten men. The dining-room
of the dormitory will be for the use
of the inmates only.

Freshmen Numerals Awarded.

At the last meeting of the Class
of 1919, it was decided that the
numerals should be immediately
awarded to those who had been on
the class football, basket-ball and
track teams. The captain of the
basket-ball team has not as yet made
his report.
Captain Sill, of the freshman
track squad, has recently announced
the names of the men receiving
numerals for track work. They
are as follows: Haskell, Reese,
Weech, Shawn, Geis, McCormick,
Williams, Guttmacher, Reed and
Sonneborn. The entire list of those
winning their numerals in the
freshman-sophomore football game
has not as yet been received by the
freshman authorities. The names
received thus far are Schmidt,
Myer, Frisch, R. A. Cox, E. Wasserman, Kirk, Clayton, Beetham,
Refoyer, Heck, Sonneborn, McGuigan, Fields, • Stanley, Benson
and Frock.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 22, 1916.

THE McCOY HALL CONCERT

The fortieth anniversary of the
founding of Johns Hopkins University is being celebrated today—
Tuesday, February 22.
The address of the day is to be
delivered by his Excellency, Dr.
V. K. Wellington Koo, the Chinese
Minister at Washington. The opening prayer will be given by Rev.
John McDowell, of Brown Memorial Church. During the course of
the exercises, President Goodnow
will make some announcements in
• regards to plans for the University
for the coming year.
The exercises are to begin
promptly at i i o'clock. The faculty
and students will march into the assembly room • of McCoy Hall at
10.4.5. The trustees, the faculty.
the Alumni Council and the official
guests will assemble in Levering
Hall at io.30; at 10.20 the graduate students will assemble in Room
io of McCoy Hall, the medical students in Room 12 and the undergraduates in Room ii. The families of the trustees and faculty will
have seats reserved, for them until
10.45. After the procession has
entered the assembly hall, the remaining seats will be thrown open
tr' the public.
Immediately after the exercises
in McCoy Hall, the Hopkins Club
will hold an informal luncheon for
its members. The holding of such
a luncheon (11 Commemoration Day
has become a tradition with the
club, and always arouses great interest. The House Committee has
sent out invitations to every man
enrolled upon the books, and the
number of acceptants is expected to
be even larger than usual.
This evening, the alumni will hold
their annual meeting and banquet.
The meeting will be held at the
Emerson Hotel at 7 P. M., followed
immediately by the banquet. The
committee in charge of the latter
function consists of J. Perhbroke
Thorn (chairman), Eveleth W.
Bridgman, Robertson Griswold and
Guy T. 0. Hollyday. •
Club to Give Luncheon.

The Johns Hopkins Club will
hold a luncheon today. for all its
members. The House Committee
has sent out invitations to every
man enrolled, and a large crowd
is expected to be present.
- For several years it has been the
custom of the club to give such a
luncheon at the close of the exercises on Commemoration Day.

JOHNS HOPKINS MOVES TO HOMEWOOD THIS FALL
TO BE AT HOMEWOOD NEXT FALL
Entire University to Be Moved by Next
Scholastic Year --Various Departments to Be Lodged in Structures Now Completed.

Plans for the change of site of
Johns Hopkins University have
been completed. The University
will begin its next scholastic year
tt Homewood.
The announcement of the decision
of the Board of Trustees to move
this coming fall was made by President Goodnow at the beginning of
the year. It is only lately, however,
that the final details of the plans for
removal have been completed, .and
that a definite idea of the conditions under which the new era at
Homewood will begin has shaped
itself.
Contrary to the opinion at first
prevalent after President Goodflow's announcement, the removal
will not be only partial, but will
include practically every department
of the University. The final arrangements for the housing of each
department are now being formulated, and, while these arrangements arranged that is is confidently excannot be announced as abso:utely pected that these provisions will be

The Physics department will be
lodged in the Engineering Building, although what part of that
structure it will occupy has not as
yet been decided.
It is only the location of the
Chemistry department for next
year which is still doubtful. It is
possible that it will also be placed
in one of the Engineering Buildings, but it is far more probable
that either a temporary building
will be erected for it, or that, for
the time being, it will remain at its
present location. The construction
of a temporary building would entail the expenditure of several thousand dollars, and only a strong feeling on the part of the Trustees and
Faculty that it is advisable for the
entire University to be located at
one spot, and for no single department to remain at the present
Monument street location, will make
the erection of such a building at
all likely.
With the possible exception of
this one department, the entire University will open the next scholastic
year at its new site. Preparations
for the removal are already under
way; each department has been at
work for at least a year upon the
details of its removal.
The plans for the removal of the
library, which presented the most
intricate problem of all, have been
definitely completed. Dr. Raney
has been authorized to proceed with
the actual moving of the books
whenever he sees fit, and, by summer, it is expected that the greater
part of the library will be installed
in its place in the Academic Building.

Although definite plans have not
yet been formulated for the dormitory system at Homewood, the following is the general plan: It is
proposed to build a dormitory with
accommodations for one hundred
men on the Charles street front, immediately back Of the old Carroll
Mansion. The dormitory itself
consist of a main building with two
wings running back, leaving an
open court between them. It will
be fireproof throughout and will be
heated and lighted by the present
power-house. There will be no private baths in the dormitory, but
there will be a shower for every
eight or ten men. The dining-room
of the dormitory will be for the use

CONTAINS 145 STATE STUDENTS
145 Out of 148 Students Enrolled in Engineering School Come from Maryland --Faculty Increased to
Meet the Growth.

Freshmen Numerals Awarded.

At the last meeting of the Class
of 1919, it was decided that the
numerals should be immediately
awarded to those who had been on
the class football, basket-ball and
track teams. The captain of the
basket-ball team has not as yet made
his report.
Captain Sill, of the freshman
track squad, has recently announced
the names of the men receiving
numerals for track work. They
are as follows: Haskell, Reese,
Weech, Shawn, Geis, McCormick,
Williams, Guttmacher, Reed and
Sonneborn. The entire list of those
winning their numerals in the
freshman-sophomore football game
has not as yet been received by the
freshman authorities. The names
received thus far are Schmidt,
Myer, Frisch, R. A. Cox, E. Wasserman, Kirk, Clayton, Beetham,
Refoyer, Heck, Sonneborn, McGuigan, Fields, • Stanley, Benson
and Frock.
